column4: Does anyone know why the spelling checker used by gedit complains about "shouldn't"
and if there's any way to teach it to understand the use of the apostrophe
because it's poor english.
only in some contexts.
it's certainly not misspelled English.
just out of curiousity.. why spell-check in gedit?   idk what it uses though, probably just the gnu spellcheck library.
because I'm writing in gedit.
and regardless of whether I use it or not, it's a clear bug.
why?  just add it to your dictionary :)
that shouldn't be necessary.
it's quite ordinary English
*shrug* I really do suppose that depends on where you come from.
to answer your question, it uses the aspell library for spellcheck.
It doesn't really depend where you come from. Contractions are not a spelling error. They may be inappropriate style in some instances.

hmm, you probably are right that it's a bug.  you might consider submitting it with aspell.  "shouldn't" is already in the American English dictionary and it is the only contraction that appears to cause a spellcheck error.
What's particularly interesting is that you "fix" it and end up with "shouldn't't"  lol
which of course ends up being "wrongly" spelled ;)
the issue though isn't the word, it's the single-quote barrier that apperas to be the issue.
yes using aspell at the command line with en_GB and input "shouldn't shouldnt can't cant" only "shouldnt" is marked as being spelled incorrectly
hmm but in gedit "shouldn't shouldnt can't cant" both shouldn'ts are marked as incorrectly spelled
they are, and if you "fix" them you'll find "shouldn" can be replaced with "shouldn't" leaving you with "shouldn't't"
which of course, "shouldn't't" will be marked as incorrectly spelled, lol.  It appears to only be that word though, which is why I'm with you on the belief that it's a flaw with ASpell.
well, I think there's a problem with Aspell /and/ a different problem with gedit. Because otherwise I can't explain the difference between the two.
oh, interesting.  I see what you're saying. Interesting.
